head.title: A Father of the Grand Skyline

hedline.hl1: A Father of the Grand Skyline

block.p: THE ''City Beautiful'' movement was in full flower a century ago, and the architect Cass Gilbert (1859-1934) brought its ideals into tangible form. His United States Custom House on Bowling Green (shown above in a 1900 rendering) is a grand monument to New York's role in world trade. That celebrated structure and Gilbert's Gothic-styled Woolworth Building are among the subjects of an exhibition opening Tuesday at the New-York Historical Society, ''Inventing the Skyline: The Architecture of Cass Gilbert.''

In addition to the show's sketches and photographs, there will be a series of free related public programs in October including a panel on architecture and public life, a symposium and panel on the New York skyline, and a walking tour of the Upper West Side. Though the programs are free, reservations are required.

THE ''City Beautiful'' movement was in full flower a century ago, and the architect Cass Gilbert (1859-1934) brought its ideals into tangible form. His United States Custom House on Bowling Green (shown above in a 1900 rendering) is a grand monument to New York's role in world trade. That celebrated structure and Gilbert's Gothic-styled Woolworth Building are among the subjects of an exhibition opening Tuesday at the New-York Historical Society, ''Inventing the Skyline: The Architecture of Cass Gilbert.''

In addition to the show's sketches and photographs, there will be a series of free related public programs in October including a panel on architecture and public life, a symposium and panel on the New York skyline, and a walking tour of the Upper West Side. Though the programs are free, reservations are required.

''Inventing the Skyline: The Architecture of Cass Gilbert'' Tuesday through Jan. 21; Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, at Central Park West; $5; students and people over 65, $3; children 12 and under free; for more information and the full schedule of programs, (212) 873-3400.
